thread.title: Reg Sprigg honoured with SA's first fossil emblem
thread.title_full: Reg Sprigg honoured with SA's first fossil emblem

author: Nicola Gage
title: Reg Sprigg honoured with SA's first fossil emblem
text:
Map: Parachilna 5730 
The man who first documented Ediacara fossils, the late Dr Reg Sprigg, is again being recognised, with South Australia's first state fossil emblem named after him. 
But it was not an easy road for him to prove the worth of his discovery, with explorer and geologist Sir Douglas Mawson initially unconvinced it was anything significant. 
That conversation only gave Dr Sprigg more passion to forge ahead with his work, according to his son. 
He visited his close friend and mentor, Sir Douglas, at the South Australian Museum in the 1940s to talk about fossils. 
At the time, Dr Sprigg was building his career as a geologist, working in South Australia's Flinders Ranges. Photo: Sir Douglas Mawson needed to be convinced about Dr Sprigg's discoveries. (Supplied) 
Dr Sprigg was adamant he had come across a goldmine of ancient treasures, which could have been some of the oldest forms of animal life on earth. 
What he had found were imprints of what looked like worm or crustacean-like creatures on the hard layers of sandstone in the region. 
The story goes, according to Dr Sprigg's son, Doug, his enthusiasm was first met with hesitation by Sir Douglas. 
"There had been discoveries before that had turned out not to be correct and I think Mawson was keen to protect dad from finding out that he wasn't right," he said. Geologists 'stuck to his guns' 
However, Dr Sprigg was right and the fossils, now believed to be more than half a billion years old, had not been documented anywhere in the world. 
Doug Sprigg said his father had faith that other geologists would soon recognise the fossil's worth. Photo: The Spriggina fossil was named in Dr Reg Sprigg's honour. (Supplied) 
He soon convinced Sir Douglas that the imprints were more than just natural markings on the rock. 
"Dad stuck to his guns and it turned out that is was the oldest complex life on earth," Mr Sprigg said. 
Partly due to this research, Dr Sprigg is now one of Australia's most celebrated geologists and conservationists. 
One fossil he found, which has only been located in the Flinders Ranges, was named the Spriggina, in honour of him. He loved science and the natural world 
It is now South Australia's first fossil emblem, an announcement that Doug Sprigg said his father would be humbled by. 
"He wasn't too big-headed about things, he wasn't worried about his part in the process," he said. 
"He was interested in understanding evolution and life. 
"Being with him was a bit like being with Sir David Attenborough he couldn't help but be emerged by things and he had a love of science and the natural world around him." 
"He was an economic geologist but he recognised that conservation was going to become more and more important." 
Mr Sprigg said he hoped creating a state fossil emblem would lead to more people studying geology. 
"I hope it gets kids more interested in sciences, there's going to be lots more discoveries," he said. 
"We're only scratching the surface of that life development and there are bits missing along the way from there on to where we are now."
